In the long term, rent control has been shown to improve housing affordability for several reasons. First, it prevents landlords from raising rents excessively, which can price out low-income families and force them to move. By capping rent increases, rent control ensures that tenants can afford to stay in their homes and communities.

Second, rent control encourages landlords to maintain their properties and invest in necessary repairs and upgrades. Since they can't simply raise rents to cover these costs, they have an incentive to keep their buildings in good condition. This leads to better housing quality for tenants over time.

Finally, rent control helps to slow down the rate of gentrification in neighborhoods. Rent control helps to prevent this displacement by keeping housing costs stable for existing tenants.

The primary goal of rent control is to make housing more affordable for tenants by limiting how much and how often landlords can raise rents. Proponents argue this provides stability and prevents low-income residents from being priced out of their homes and neighborhoods.

However, the majority of economic research finds that rent control has negative long-term effects on housing affordability and availability overall. A 2019 survey of 44 economists found 79% agreeing that "a city-wide rent control ordinance...would probably not make housing more affordable overall." [1]

The main reasons are that rent control disincentivizes new housing construction and leads to lower maintenance and eventual removal of existing housing from the market. Landlords have less incentive to build or maintain units if they can't raise rents to cover costs. Over time, this shrinks the housing supply, driving up prices for non-controlled units. [2][3]

Studies of rent control in cities like San Francisco and New York have found it results in higher rents overall, reduced housing supply, and increased segregation by income and race. [4][5] Rent control also tends to benefit higher-income, longer-term tenants rather than those with lower incomes or who move more frequently. [6]

That said, there is some debate over the magnitude of these effects and whether certain types of rent control (e.g. vacancy decontrol, rent stabilization) may be less distortionary than strict rent caps. [7] Some argue rent control can still be a useful short-term tool if paired with other pro-housing policies.

Overall, while the intent of rent control is to improve affordability, the weight of evidence suggests it is an ineffective tool that often exacerbates the problems it aims to solve in the long run. Most experts believe a better approach is to increase housing supply through zoning reform and relax building height limits, while providing targeted assistance to low-income renters. [8]

This is a complex issue and there are important nuances to consider. But in summary, while well-intentioned, rent control policies tend to do more harm than good when it comes to improving housing affordability and availability over the long term. Increasing the housing supply directly is likely to be more effective.
